FacilityName: MPLX Terminals LLC - Lansing LP Terminal
LEPC: Clinton Co Dept of Emerg Serv

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES



MPLX Terminals, LLC - Lansing LP Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Lansing LP Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Lansing, MI. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.



The Lansing LP Terminal, located in Lansing, MI, is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Marathon believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment (HES) goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.



The Lansing LP Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of our employees, contractors and the community. Marathon promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection along with the process safety principles in RC14001. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Marathon has developed and implemented, including:



A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;

B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;

C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;

D. An overview of the emergency response program; and

E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.



A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The primary function of the Lansing LP Terminal is to act as a refined petroleum distribution facility. The butane blending process

has been classified as Program Level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances were identified. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. The Lansing LP Terminal is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health.  Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety systems incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Lansing LP Terminal.



The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) storage vessel. Specifically, liquefied butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure. The butane is then pumped to a blending/injection skid for direct injection into blend grade and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via the blending skid, Bartec-Benke, and PLC Analyzer. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, fusible elements (<250 degrees Fahrenheit), pneumatic valves (fail safe), 85% fill shutoff on the vessel, emergency shut-off devices on the system and video display terminal, line thermal (pressure) reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the Lansing LP Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.



B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION MEASURES



Marathon accidental release prevention and emergency planning/response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by the Terminal's regulated substances to its employees, the public, and

the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  The following accident prevention program elements are in place at the Lansing LP Terminal:



1) Employee Participation,

2) Process Safety Information,

3) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA),

4) Operating Procedures,

5) Operator and Contractor Training,

6) Contractor Safety,

7) Pre-Startup Safety Review,

8) Mechanical Integrity with Preventive Maintenance,

9) Hazardous Work Permits,

10) Management of Change,

11) Incident Investigation Procedures/Reporting,

12) Emergency Response Action Plans,

13) Compliance Audits, and 

14) Trade Secrets.



These fourteen (14) individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Marathon and its employees are committed to the standards required by these management programs. In addition to the above elements, the Lansing LP Terminal also has specific prevention measures that are employed as part of our operating procedures along with engineering and administrative controls to prevent a release, quickly detect a release, and reduce the consequences of a release.  These are briefly summarized as follows:



General Risk Reduction and Safety Measures



-Engineering and construction in accordance with Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices and company standards;

-Equipment properly designed with protection from overpressure (pressure safety relief valves, etc.);

-Updated technical drawings, Piping & Instrument Diagrams and Process/Block Flow Diagrams;

-Operating systems monitored and controlled by trained Operators (both on-site and remotely);

-Computerized monitoring and automated process controls;

-Redundant control systems with uninterruptable power supply; 

-Automatic and manual shutdown devices for critical systems;

-Scheduled inspection and testing of instruments, analyzers, and safe

the Looking Glass Regional Fire Authority. A Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place to inform employees about what to do in case of a release and/or fire including notification of emergency responders when there is a need for a response. 



The Looking Glass Regional Fire Authority has participated in initial butane process and response training.  Periodic exercises ranging from notification to full-scale are conducted.



E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Marathon is continually striving to make the Lansing LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.



In an effort to promote a process safety culture, employees complete multiple PSM and RMP related education opportunities along with establishing regular terminal representative meetings and maintaining consistent communication with its butane business partner.



Additionally, Marathon is a RC14001 company and employs API 754 practices to report, track, and evaluate leading and lagging indicators.
